newsitem.title: CHINA: U.S., China to open negotiations on textiles.
newsitem.headline: U.S., China to open negotiations on textiles.

text.p: The United States and China will open talks Tuesday aimed at forging a new pact on textile trade, officials said Monday.
Top U.S. textile negotiator Rita Hayes of the U.S. Trade Representative's Office arrived in Beijing arrived on Sunday, a U.S. Embassy official said.
The talks were scheduled to start Tuesday, an official of China's Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation said, but declined to give further details.
The bilateral textile accord had been scheduled to expire on Dec. 31 last year but was extended by one month amid progress in talks on renewing the 1994 agreement.
Negotiators will also try to resolve a dispute involving U.S. penalties on imports of Chinese textiles and China's threat to retaliate.
Washington slapped $19 million of penalties on imports of Chinese textiles last September, saying Beijing was shipping textiles through third countries to evade quota restrictions.
China has threatened to retaliate by temporarily banning imports of some U.S. textiles, farm goods and alcoholic drinks but has delayed such action to allow time for further talks.
The two sides failed to reach agreement on the issue in talks in the United States last month. Washington said then it would re-examine its decision to reduce quotas for Chinese textile imports.
China's textile sales to the United States have long been a sensitive point for U.S. trade negotiators, who are eager to reduce Washington's swelling trade deficit.

The United States said its trade deficit with China was $29 billion in the first nine months of last year, making trade a major issue in ties already strained by disputes over Taiwan, copyright piracy and weapons sales.
China says its customs figures show a surplus in favour of the United States.
